subject.geographic: Alvin Roy's Slenderizing Salon and Turkish Baths (Baton Rouge, La.)

mods.abstract: Ray Roy provides biographical details on his experiences growing up in Baton Rouge and speaks at length about his older brother Alvin. Ray discusses Alvin's purchase of the gym (Alvin Roy's Slenderizing Salon and Turkish Baths), the years that he and Alvin worked in the gym together (mid 1950s through late 70s), the struggles of keeping the business afloat, descriptions of the gym and surrounding neighborhood, the prominent sports figures who trained there, Alvin's work setting up weight training programs for multiple pro football teams, and Alvin's family. There is also a discussion of football teams and rivalries in the Baton Rouge area prior to integration.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.1743. A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Petra Munro Hendry.

Ray Roy was born in 1931, the youngest of seven children. His parents were Joseph Thomas Roy and Lula Marie Major. He attended Saint Anthony grade school and Catholic High School, graduating in 1948. He attended Louisiana State University for two years, then joined the U.S. Navy for four years and served in the Korean War. After he left the service in 1954, he worked with his brother, Alvin, in his gym on Oklahoma Street in Baton Rouge. Alvin was an internationally known weight lifting and strength trainer. Ray Roy married his wife Glenda in 1962.
